title: Transforming Federal Customer Experience and Service Delivery To Rebuild Trust in Government
summary: Directs Federal agencies to improve their service delivery and customer experience for the American people.
full_text: Directs Federal agencies to improve their service delivery and customer experience for the American people.
plain_language_summary:
Improving Federal Service Delivery and Customer Experience

Overview: Directs federal agencies to enhance service delivery and customer experience to restore trust in government. Aims to make it easier for the public to access federal services and benefits.

Bottom Line: Universities should monitor how this order affects interactions with federal agencies, especially around research funding.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Research Grants: Application and reporting processes for federal research grants may be streamlined.

Data Sharing: Increased emphasis on data sharing between agencies could impact reporting requirements.

Public Engagement: Opportunities may arise to provide input on improving higher education-related federal services.

Important Dates:

  • 12/13/2021: Executive order issued

Affected Departments:

Sponsored Projects Office, Research Administration, Government Relations

Action Plan:

Action Required: No immediate action required, but relevant offices should track implementation progress.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Review order and identify potential impact areas
  • Discuss implications with affected departments

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Monitor agency implementation plans
  • Engage with professional associations tracking this issue

Long-term Considerations:

  • Proactively provide input on customer experience improvements
  • Adapt processes to streamlined grant requirements

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: No additional personnel needed

Budget: No significant budget impact

Technology: May need to update grants management systems

External Expertise: Rely on sector associations for implementation details
executive_brief:
Executive Brief

Requires federal agencies to improve service delivery to rebuild public trust. May impact grants, research funding, and reporting for universities.
comprehensive_analysis:
Transforming Federal Customer Experience and Service Delivery

Overview: Executive Order 14058 directs federal agencies to make government services and benefits more accessible and user-friendly for the American people. It requires agencies to modernize programs, reduce administrative burdens, and pilot new online tools and technologies. The overall goal is to restore public trust in government by making federal services easier to navigate and more responsive.

Bottom Line: While not directly targeted at higher education, this order could lead to changes in how universities interact with federal agencies on grants, reporting, and regulatory compliance. Institutions should stay informed on implementation and look for opportunities to provide constructive feedback.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

Builds on previous efforts to modernize government services, but signals increased prioritization under the Biden administration.

Legal Framework:

Directs but does not mandate agency actions, sets general direction that will be shaped by Congressional oversight and funding.

Higher Education Context:

Aligns with growing focus on user-centered design and customer experience in higher education services.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Research Grant Administration: Applying for and managing federal research grants may become less burdensome as agencies streamline processes and reporting.

Student Financial Aid: Students could see improved customer experience around federal financial aid services from the Department of Education.

Regulatory Compliance: Reduced administrative burdens could ease compliance with certain higher education regulations.

Data Privacy and Security: As agencies improve data sharing, universities will need to ensure student and research data remains protected.

Stakeholder Engagement: Institutions can provide valuable insights to agencies on improving higher education services and processes.

Important Dates:

  • 12/13/2021: Executive order issued
  • Ongoing: Agency implementation (specific timelines TBD)

Affected Departments:

Sponsored Projects Office, Research Administration, Government Relations, Institutional Compliance, Financial Aid Office

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

No specific compliance requirements for universities, but changes in agency processes may alter reporting and documentation.

Technical Analysis:

Modernizing legacy IT systems will be a major challenge for agencies, interoperability issues could affect grants management systems.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

Improved federal service delivery could benefit student aid, university research, and other areas that intersect with federal funding and regulation.

Risk Analysis:

Low risk of non-compliance as order does not mandate university action, but important to engage early on agency reforms.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Institutions that proactively align with federal customer experience goals could benefit from funding and partnership opportunities.

Long-term Vision:

Contributes to a more user-friendly and streamlined higher education landscape with fewer administrative burdens.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Universities can share expertise and ideas for improving federal services related to higher education.

Action Plan:

Action Required: No statutory requirements for universities, but implementation should be closely tracked and opportunities for input pursued.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Review the full executive order text
  • Brief relevant departments on potential implications
  • Identify impact areas and assign monitoring responsibilities
  • Engage with campus government relations team

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Monitor implementation plans published by agencies
  • Engage with professional associations and peer institutions
  • Submit comments or feedback on draft agency plans

Long-term Considerations:

  • Align service delivery improvements with institutional goals
  • Proactively develop higher ed service enhancement ideas
  • Advocate for research university priorities in agency plans

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: No dedicated personnel, but should allocate staff time to tracking and engaging on implementation.

Budget: No direct budget impact, potential indirect benefits from reduced administrative costs.

Technology: May need to update IT systems for research administration and financial aid to adapt to agency changes.

External Expertise: Leverage knowledge of professional associations, university peers, and former agency officials.
